text:
RT @LucyStats: Dear @CDCgov & @WHCOVIDResponse,

Please stop reporting the % hospitalized that were unvaxed, we expect this % to *decrease*â€¦

Excellent read (with colorful graphics unique for an academic paper) on the false dichotomies of the pandemic and the need for more nuanced thinking across shades of gray for many topics. https://t.co/572EUhfMwe
Brilliant application of seminal work in sociology to understand COVID deniers and anti vaxxers and identify strategies to address them. https://t.co/Ie1jw36YAj

RT @davidwdowdy: If you're in the US right now, how worried should you be about the recent uptick in COVID cases?

A plain-language threadâ€¦

Across LMICs, 4 in 5 people indicated they would be willing to receive a COVID-19 vaccine (see GAVI link). Low vaccination rates in the Global South aren't an issue of demand: they're an issue of supply.

Image: @MaxCRoser @OurWorldInData  https://t.co/MZBCHpvLjA https://t.co/B6fQSM25ss

"What we found was a scale of family loss that has not been seen since AIDS first rampaged through sub-Saharan Africa." 

The researchers estimated a child in the world loses a caregiver every 12 seconds to COVID-19. Sit with that stat for a minute.

https://t.co/PpqxoZecD2
On estimating excess deaths due to COVID-19 in India, with thoughtful caveats and considerations around three different methods: https://t.co/tHPOnBT4uc
Support a great humanitarian organization & an easy way to thank @jburnmurdoch if you've relied on his COVID-19 charts over the last year and a half. https://t.co/4nDmv4w1tt

@shazmaroni @JSIhealth The @BIDInitiative focused on connecting countries to share what worked in regards to improved routine immunization data (and COVID has reinforced how critical quality information is to effective distribution of resources). https://t.co/ZpOWAKmnA3

In a globally connected world, countries hoarding vaccines rather than sharing is an ethical & logical failure. The continued spread of COVID in other countries impacts the US too.

I'm also disappointed to see misinformed replies to @uche_blackstock's post. Debunking a few /1 https://t.co/eiJli7XtZO

@EpiEllie @JohnsHopkinsCCP I don't know if they're currently collecting information on history of diagnosis with COVID, but it's one of the  few long term KAP surveys I've seen that is across multiple countries.

We can't ignore the other public health crises we face as a nation as we continue to battle COVID-19.

And after our #ChartChat with @_rospearce, I immediately notice the right-orientation of the y-axis on @TheEconomist charts. https://t.co/zM7Buddye9

@chezVoila To figure out what precisely? @tableau maintained and updated their COVID-19 data hub, @datadotworld made their cleaned data with detailed documentation available and open sourced all of their graphics. And folks certainly created graphics with those sources.

@xangregg @chezVoila Firmly agree - especially in the early months of the pandemic. Charts imply a certain factfulness and objectivity and  case data was plagued with reporting delays, inconsistencies, and other challenges.

@chezVoila @COVID19Tracking @jburnmurdoch @danielle_ivory @ReutersGraphics @nytimes Could other #dataviz experts have done the same? Absolutely - that piece of the process should be part of any project we undertake (with even higher stakes in the early stages of a pandemic). But there were so many unknowns in those early months that context and SMEs were needed.

@chezVoila @COVID19Tracking Data journalists and others who have been lauded for their visuals (@jburnmurdoch @danielle_ivory @ReutersGraphics @nytimes to name a few) invested time learning the nuances of the data, finding ways to communicate uncertainty, and engaging with subject matter experts.

@chezVoila Over time, and through often volunteer efforts that included a mix of data, viz, epi, and other experts (like @COVID19Tracking), charts evolved with more nuanced encodings of reporting anomalies, better footnotes, and more data documentation.

It saddens (but doesn't surprise) me to hear how demoralized many in public health have become as their evidence based policy recs are drowned out by the 'pandemic is over' and 'no mask mandates!' chorus.
